newsitem.title: USA: Clinton accepts VA head Brown's resignation.
newsitem.headline: Clinton accepts VA head Brown's resignation.

text.p: President Clinton accepted the resignation of Veterans Affairs Secretary Jesse Brown Saturday and thanked him for his "unceasing commitment to the rights of veterans."
In a letter to Brown, a partially disabled Marine combat veteran, Clinton said he accepted "with deep regret" the decision to leave his post effective July 1.
"Your many contributions will long stand as evidence of your unceasing commitment to the rights of veterans and the honour they deserve," Clinton said.

White House officials said Clinton has not chosen a successor for Brown, one of highest ranking blacks in the administration. One official, however, pointed out that the department's deputy secretary, Hershel Gober, is a close friend of the president.

Brown, a former Marine who was wounded in Vietnam, said in his letter of resignation that he was leaving his post after more than four years because its "responsibilities are too important to be treated or considered as career employment."
"To do so, would not be in the best interest of our veterans," he said.
Saying he had "great ambivalence" about his decision, Brown told Clinton, "It is now time for me to step aside and allow someone else to carry the cause to even greater heights."
White House officials said they were not surprised by Brown's resignation, noting that he had indicated last year that he did not intend to serve a second full term as head of the department.
Brown, who had worked for the Disabled American Veterans organisation before becoming a Cabinet officer in 1993, was ambushed in a Vietnamese rice paddy, leaving him with a paralysed right arm.
"In 1965, in one short moment, my life was changed by a shot I never heard," Brown recalled in his letter of resignation.

"Over the succeeding 32 years, I have been driven by an obsession to make sure that veterans, whose lives have also been changed, are not disadvantaged by having honourably served in the military," said Brown.
The Veterans Administration is one of the largest of the departments in the federal government, with a budget of $41 billion annually.
